patterns: What are the requirements to purchase a property insurance policy?
responses: The proposal form should disclose all details, which are true to the insured’s best knowledge and other information, which the proposer may feel is relevant.

patterns: How is condo insurance different from homeowner insurance?
responses: When you purchase a condominium, you are not purchasing the building; you are purchasing a unit inside the building. You are also most likely a part of a condo corporation that fixes external structural damages.

patterns: If my garage burns down and my car is in the garage, is my car covered under my homeowners insurance or car insurance?
responses: Your homeowners insurance does not cover the loss of your car, even though it was, “in your house.” You typically must have a form of comprehensive physical damage coverage on your automobile insurance policy for it to be covered.

patterns: I have taken home insurance policies with two companies. What happens in case of claim settlement?
responses: In case you have taken home insurance policies from two different companies, you will be paid on a proportionate basis in the event of a claim being made.

patterns: If the insured house is sold, what happens to the home insurance policy?
responses: In case the insured house is sold, the policy stands cancelled from the moment the transfer of ownership of the house takes place and the insured ceases to be covered under the policy. Following this, the balance of the premium for the remaining insured period shall be refunded to the policy holder.

patterns: What if some of my personal property is in the basement, is it covered ?
responses: if your personal property is stored in the basement closet or cage of your condo or apartment, it’s covered because it’s still at your home address.
For personal property stored in a self-storage facility, or usually stored at a different place, our policy covers you for theft up to a certain limit.

patterns: How do I add extra coverage for my expensive items?
responses: How do I add extra coverage for my expensive items?
No. Renters and homeowners insurance only covers you and the property that you legally own. Your roommate will need to get their own insurance policy.
Coverage for laptops, phones, tablets, TVs, and other personal electronics are all included, as standard, in the policy.
You'll be happy to know that your policy automatically covers all residents of your household, who are related to you by marriage, blood, or adoption

patterns: Why aren't floods and earthquakes covered by my homeowners policy?
responses: ( FOR US),Flood and earthquake activity is more widespread than many people realize. Nine out of ten Americans live in seismically active areas. Since 1900, earthquakes have occurred in 39 states and caused damage in all 50. And if your home is located in a flood-prone area, you are 26 times more likely to suffer flood damage than fire damage.

patterns: Are there any other exclusion I should know about?
responses: There may be other exclusions spelled out in your policy such as neglect, intentional loss, 'earth movement (landslide)', general power failure and even damage caused by war. If you neglect to take care of your property (i.e., a leaky roof), you may not be covered. One other exclusion that can be costly is the Ordinance or Law exclusion.

patterns: What insurance will cover my Church ?
responses: Every church needs two types of insurance: property and liability (casualty). Property insurance covers the things the church owns and should be calculated based on what it would cost to replace them (replacement cost value). Liability insurance covers actions that could leave the church liable for damage to others, including injuries, possessions, and reputations.

patterns: If a contractor or one of his employees gets hurt while working on my property; can they sue me?
responses: If they have workers compensation that would take care of them. If they do not have workers compensation; you could end up in a law suit (if you were liable for why they got hurt).

patterns: If a neighbor’s tree falls on my car or house due to a storm, does my neighbor’s homeowners fix my car or house?
responses: No, it does not. The tree falling over is due to an act of God, not your neighbor’s neglect or them trying to take the tree down themselves and it falling the wrong way.

patterns: What about our vacation home in another state, is it covered?
responses: Because insurance companies can operate in more than one state, the company that carries your primary residence may issue a policy for your vacation home. Personal liability is covered in the first homeowners policy, so the second policy needs to cover only property. This second type of policy is called a 'dwelling policy.'

patterns: I work out of my home. Are my inventory and business property covered?
responses: Yes, within certain limits. Both inventory and business property are covered as personal property used for business purposes. However, like all personal property, there are monetary limits on reimbursement.

patterns: Help! I've lost everything! Where do I start?
responses: Now is the time to make a list of major house, hold items and possessions. To make the job easier a home inventory form is available by clicking here. Where possible, it is wise to list the items' serial number, the date and the cost of purchase and the receipt. Perhaps an even easier way to inventory your home is to use a still or video camera. As you take the video, you also can talk about the items, when you purchased them and how much they cost.

patterns: Why does my insurance company want to know where the nearest fire hydrant to my home is located?
responses: The insurance company has to weigh many factors in determining a premium to charge for your policy. One factor is access to water (hence the question about the location of the nearest fire hydrant) as well as the dependability and proximity of your local fire company and police. Rural homes more than five miles from a water supply are more at risk for severe damage from fire and lightning. Therefore, they can be more expensive to insure. Rural homeowners may even have difficulty obtaining insurance.

patterns: What if I am sued or found responsible for injuring another person?
responses: Liability covers bodily injury and property damage to others due to your negligence. The coverage applies to non-auto accidents that occur either at your residence or off the premises. You may owe medical expense payments, such as first aid, to the injured party. Should you be sued as a result of your negligent actions or suspect that you might be sued

patterns: I have termintes all over in my house, will my policy take care of it ?
responses: No, destruction by termites or pests in not covered

patterns: what are the things which will increase my liability risk?
responses: an aggressive pet, trampoline or pool can result into more liability.

patterns: Are the backyard shed and my television covered in my homeowners policy?
responses: Covered personal property includes the contents of your home and personal belongings used, owned, worn or carried by you or members of your household-basically, everything .This coverage is also based on the house coverage, and there are limits on the losses that can be claimed.

patterns: Does my homeowners insurance cover my possessions even when I go on vacation?
responses: Yes. Homeowners insurance is a package of insurance coverage that extends to all your possessions no matter where they are.

patterns: I rent out my basement. Are my tenants covered by my homeowners policy?
responses: No. Your property and the structure (the basement) are covered by your policy, as is your personal liability. However, the tenants' possessions and liability are not covered by your policy. Therefore, they may wish to purchase their own renters insurance.

patterns: My mother-in-law lives with us. Are her possessions covered under my homeowners insurance?
responses: As a member of the family, she is probably covered under your homeowners policy. Likewise, your child away at college is covered for personal liability and property loss.

patterns: I have specifically insured antique items on my policy. If I have a total loss, would my insurance company pay me their insured value?
responses: Your insurance company would first confirm the value of the items with one or more independent antique dealers. You should then be paid a dollar value based on the dealer(s) estimate of the worth of the antique items. If you disagree with the settlement offered by your insurer, then you can follow the dispute resolution process outlined in your policy.

patterns: A tree from my neighbor's yard fell and destroyed my fence. Does my policy pay for the damage or does my neighbor's policy?
responses: Generally, your own policy should cover the loss. Your insurance company may be able to recover the amount it pays you for the loss and your deductible from the homeowners insurance that your neighbor may have, in the event that the loss occurred as a result of your neighbor's negligence.

patterns: Recent rainstorms have flooded and damaged my basement. Is there any coverage under my policy?
responses: Flood coverage is generally excluded on the basic homeowners policy. However, some homeowners policies provide coverage for backup of sewers and drains that cause flooding in your basement.

patterns: The food in my freezer went bad because I lost power in my home. Does my policy provide coverage for this?
responses: The basic homeowner policy usually does not. There is also the issue of where the power was lost. Some policies are limited to coverage for electricity lost in the home or where the electricity enters the home. Others will limit it to within so many yards from the home.

patterns: I have a dog of a particular breed and was told by some companies that they won't insure me because of my pet. Can they do this?
responses: As a dog and homeowner there are ways that you can show your insurance agent or prospective insurer that you've taken steps to mitigate any liability risk your dog may pose.Show the agent or prospective insurer that your dog has undergone obedience training with a certified trainer Show veterinary records that verify your dog has had all required immunizations Show photographs as proof that your dog can be contained from contact with visitors to your property If your dog has bitten before always disclose the nature of the incident and the steps you took to prevent a repeat occurrence.

patterns: Does my policy provide coverage for home heating oil spills?
responses: Most homeowners insurance policies do not automatically include such coverage as part of its standard homeowners insurance policy. Without the home heating oil spill cleanup coverage, you may be responsible for paying for an oil spill cleanup out of pocket

patterns: Should I consider a recent appraisal for my jewelry items (such as an engagement or anniversary ring)?
responses: Yes. The value of precious metals and gemstones is constantly changing. So even if you’ve had your jewelry appraised before, it’s always a good idea to have it appraised again for its current market value.

patterns: A pipe bursts and water flows all over my floors. Am I covered?
responses: Yes. Typically, homeowners insurance covers you for accidental discharge of water from a plumbing system.

patterns: Am I covered for earthquake damage?
responses: No. Earthquake coverage is available as a separate coverage.

patterns: Why is my home’s estimated reconstruction cost different than the new construction cost?
responses: One is economies of scale and another is Labor costs are also typically higher for reconstruction compared to new construction. During reconstruction, workers may need to remove debris, demolish parts of the home, and align new materials with existing home materials. These processes are more labor intensive and as a result, more expensive.

patterns: How does one fix the sum insured?
responses: One condition is that the damaged asset should be repaired / replaced in order to get the claim. It may be noted that RIV method is allowed only for FIXED ASSETS and not for other assets like stocks and stocks in process.

patterns: My home sustained a water loss last winter due to melting ice dams on the roof. What would be covered under my policy?
responses: Generally damage to both the exterior and interior of a home resulting from weight of ice and snow or ice dams is covered under a homeowners policy. However, only the area damaged in the loss will be covered.

patterns: My home was recently broken into and I do not have sales receipts for the stolen items. What will my insurance company accept for proof of ownership?
responses: If the actual receipts are not available, insurance companies generally will accept photos, warranties, owners manuals, cancelled checks, credit card receipts, bills, servicing agreements, even video tapes, as proof of ownership.

patterns: What is not covered under buglary insurance?
responses: The following items are Not covered by the burglary plan: Precious metals (gold, silver, etc.) Cash Share certificates Items that were stolen by family members Items that were stolen by employees Items that were stolen by housemaids Loss due to war, riots, strike, terrorist activities, and natural calamities

patterns: When Should I Get Homeowners Insurance?
responses: You should purchase homeowners insurance before you contact a mortgage company for a loan.

patterns: Under what circumstances will my claim not be accepted?
responses: Under the Following Circumstances your Claim will not be Accepted- If the premises were left unattended If the premises were not locked properly locked Failure to ensure security at the premises Planned burglary to make an insurance claim

patterns: How much would it cost to rebuild my home at today's prices?
responses: The primary factors that’ll determine the cost to rebuild your home include: Local construction costs The square footage of your home (and the number of bathrooms and other rooms) The type of exterior wall construction – frame, masonry (brick or stone) or veneer The type of roof The number of floors (one to four stories, bi-level or split level) Special features like attached garages, fireplaces, exterior trim and arched windows Quality of materials and finishes throughout the home

patterns: What are the different types of home insurance deductible options?
responses: there are three common types of deductibles: A flat deductible is a specific or fixed dollar amount; A percent deductible is a percentage that it is based on the home’s dwelling coverage, A split deductible means there is a specific deductible that applies to some cause(s) of loss and a different deductible that applies to other causes of loss.

patterns: Does my liability coverage extend to vacant land I own or rent?
responses: You may extend your personal liability coverage from your home and umbrella policies to vacant land you own or rent (depending on your state and product type).

patterns: A neighbor slips on my sidewalk and threatens to take me to court for damages. Does my homeowner policy protect me?
responses: Yes. Homeowners insurance will pay for damages, if the accident is the result of your negligence. It will also pay for the legal costs of defending you against a claim and will cover medical expenses arising from an injury to a neighbour or guest

patterns: How long will it take for my insurance claim to be settled?
responses: Most people find it takes at least 18-24 months to repair/rebuild/replace their home and possessions after a large loss

patterns: What are the most common post-disaster insurance problems?
responses: Not having enough coverage ('underinsured'),Delays,Confusion over what's covered and what's not,'Lowball' estimates and settlement offers. The adjuster assigned to the claim is unpleasant or hard to work with, or Differences of opinion over scopes and values of losses

patterns: My adjuster is rushing me to complete my contents inventory, but I just can't remember everything yet.
responses: Don’t panic and use household inventory guide to recall.Don't forget to include taxes, transportation and shipping costs associated with replacing items.

patterns: My home is partially damaged, will the insurance company owe for matching?
responses: The appearance of your home after repairs have been made should be uniform and consistent. So, the insurance company will take care of this while repairing.

patterns: My insurance company keeps reducing what they're going to pay by 'depreciating' items in my claim; what can I do?
responses: The condition of an item, its age and its useful life are all factors to consider. Not everything in home can be depreciated.For example, paint, vinyl and roofing are exposed to the elements so they deteriorate depreciated. The underlying materials like studs, cement, rebar, and framing—are not.

patterns: How Do I Know If the Damage Is Covered?
responses: First, check your policy documents. If you’re still unsure, you can go ahead and begin the claims process anyway.

patterns: When Will an Adjuster Come to My Home?
responses: This depends on a few factors, like the location of your home, and the extent of the damage. If a wildfire or hurricane causes wide-spread damage in your area, it may take a while for an adjuster to make it to your home.

patterns: Am I required to have homeowners insurance if I own a home?
responses: You can legally own a home without homeowners insurance.However, if you finance your home with a mortgage, your lender most likely will require you to have home insurance coverage from damage caused by unforeseen circumstances, such as fires or natural disasters.

patterns: Will I need to show proof of ownership for property stolen from my home?
responses: Yes, you may be asked to provide proof of ownership. Providing receipts, owners manuals, warranty cards, appraisals, photographs or original manufacturer's boxes can help support your claim.

patterns: what will be the cost of fire insurance policy?
responses: The cost of a fire insurance policy or the Premium can depend on the Perils to be covered The value of the items covered  The usage of the premises proposed for insurance  The location details of the premises proposed for insurance etc. The construction of building and occupancy

patterns: How does one arrive at the value of assets in Dwellings or Offices or Industries?
responses: Other than dwellings, industrial units or offices will maintain books of accounts showing therein value of assets therefore it will not be any problem in arriving at the sum insured. In case of dwellings, one should take stock of assets under broad categories like furniture & fixtures, clothing, bed linen, kitchen equipment, electronic gadgets and arrive at the sum insured.

patterns: Why should I insure my Building? Fire can't possibly do any harm to the building.
responses: Fire and other perils (normally covered under a fire insurance policy) can cause loss / damage to buildings. There have been fire accidents that have completely destroyed multi-storey buildings. Floods can also bring about devastating losses. Similarly, Riots and Acts of Terrorism can also produce huge losses to human lives as well as property.

patterns: I need to cover my jewellery. What policy should I take?
responses: Insurers offer ‘All Risks’ policy for covering jewellery. You must ensure that your jewellery is valued correctly and you are able to show proof of valuation should a claim occur.

patterns: In a partial theft case, is FIR required?
responses: Yes, police intimation or FIR is mandatory.

patterns: what do I need for a claim?
responses: We will need government-issued Aadhaar cards, original receipts, original prescriptions. For loss or theft-related claims, we will need original receipts and police reports.

patterns: how soon can I expect to receive the money?
responses: Most people find it takes at least 18-24 months to repair/rebuild/replace their home and possessions after a large loss. Simple claims, for example OPD or small amounts, will be approved within two hours and money settled in 24 hours. Complex claims like theft or accidents will take longer.
